publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday April 24, 2019 at 03:08

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The M/E/A/N/I/N/G Records, which span 1980 to 2004, contain correspondence, manuscript drafts, reviews and publicity materials, business and financial papers, and computer disks related to the publication and operation of the journal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The M/E/A/N/I/N/G Records include correspondence, writings, production files, financial records, and other papers related to the magazine, its twenty-fifth anniversary anthology, and online editions of the magazine. Research strengths include critical work addressing the visibility of women artists, sexuality and the arts, censorship, art world racism, the legacies of modernism, artists as mothers,and visual art in the digital age.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 13 (3.5 inch disks): Restricted fragile material. Access copies of digital files may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Box 14 (original faxes): Restricted fragile material. Photocopies of the faxes have been interfiled in the original locations.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Granary Books, Inc., on the Library Associates Fund, 2007.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Production Files. II. Correspondence. III. Business Files.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Co-founded by Susan Bee and Mira Schor in 1986, M/E/A/N/I/N/G was an art publication by and for artists. The magazine focused on the visual arts, with an emphasis on feminism and painting, and also included essays from poets. Twenty issues were published in print between 1986 and 1996. An anthology was published by Duke University Press in 2000; since 2002 the magazine has been published online.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: M/E/A/N/I/N/G Records. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.
This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The M/E/A/N/I/N/G Records is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials within this series maintain the original physical organization found at time of acquisition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains materials related to M/E/A/N/I/N/G journal issues and the anthology. Materials within this series are organized under two headings: Journal Issues and Meaning Anthology.
